subskills.DESCRIPTION: Sort common objects into groups based on whether they require energy to work (e.g., flashlight, toy car) or not (e.g., book, pencil)
Demonstrate how pushing and pulling objects requires different amounts of energy by comparing the force needed to move light vs. heavy objects
Create simple sound patterns by using different amounts of energy to strike objects (soft tap vs. hard tap)
Match energy sources (sun, batteries, electricity) to common devices or objects that use them
Observe and record how the sun's energy affects the temperature of different colored objects over time
Design a simple experiment to show how wind energy can move objects of different weights and sizes
Compare and contrast the amount of light energy that reaches different locations in the classroom using a simple light meter
Build a simple circuit using a battery, wires, and bulb to demonstrate electrical energy flow
Create a basic energy chain diagram showing how energy transforms from one form to another (e.g., battery → electrical → light)
Design and conduct an investigation to determine which materials best insulate against heat energy transfer
